author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
So I just realized that you can use multi-subset algorithms (see https://ethresear.ch/t/simple-guide-to-fast-linear-combinations-aka-multiexponentiations/7238 and particularly https://github.com/ethereum/research/blob/master/fast_linear_combinations/multicombs.py#L52 ) to verify signatures across multiple epochs faster when syncing

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
The basic idea in this case would basically be you take a batch of epochs (eg. 8 epochs could work), then you batch together the keys for every subset of those 8 (eg. you batch together the keys that participated just in the first, then the keys that participated just in the second, then the keys that participated in both the first and the second but no others, then the keys that participated just in the third....)

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
For N validators this is O(N) work, and it then cuts the per-epoch number of additions you need to do to ~128

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
So you save up to 8x in the limit

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
But this is only a history syncing optimization, not a real time processing optimization ðŸ˜¢

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
For real time processing there is an exponential time-memory tradeoff option (ie. 2^k times more memory for a k-factor speedup) but given how memory is already a bottleneck that seems like a bad idea ðŸ˜‚
